title-group.article-title: Laparoscopic Surgery in the Management of Hypersplenism and Esophagogastric Varices
title-group.subtitle: Our Initial Experiences

abstract.p: Background. Owing to recent advances in laparoscopic surgery, devascularization of the upper stomach with splenectomy (Spx) or Hassab’s procedure (Has) as well as Spx for patients with portal hypertension have been attempted laparoscopically in some facilities, the results of which have been reported. This article describes the authors’ surgical techniques and their results. Methods. Between August 1999 and August 2010, the authors treated 110 cases of portal hypertension with Spx or Has. Among these patients, 56 who simultaneously underwent additional major operations were eliminated from the study, leaving 54 patients eligible. They included 38 with open surgeries and 16 with laparoscopic surgeries, which consisted of 10 splenectomies and 6 Has operations. The perioperative data for the 2 groups were compared. Results. Purely laparoscopic Spx (L-Spx) was completed for 9 patients. Conversion from laparoscopic to hand-assisted laparoscopic surgery (HALS) was necessary for 1 patient because of poor visualization. Operative time was significantly longer in L-Spx than in the open method. Postoperative hospital stays were shorter for L-Spx. HALS was used for all 6 laparoscopic Has patients. There was no conversion from the laparoscopic to the open method. Operative time was significantly longer for laparoscopic Has than for open Has. Postoperative complication rates were significantly reduced, and postoperative hospital stays were significantly shorter for laparoscopic Has. Conclusions. Although the data are still preliminary, laparoscopic surgery for patients with portal hypertension may prove to be a successful strategy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hemorrhage from esophagogastric varices is the major complication in patients with portal hypertension. Although most patients nowadays can be treated with endoscopic methods, there are some who need to be treated surgically with a measure such as devascularization of the upper stomach (Hassab’s procedure, Has).1,2 On the other hand, splenectomy (Spx) has been performed to improve pancytopenia in cirrhotic patients undergoing hepatectomy for hepatocellular carcinoma3,4 and prior to the induction of interferon for hepatitis C infection.5

Laparoscopic Spx (L-Spx) is widely accepted as a standard treatment for hematological disorders, such as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, and has been shown to be superior to open Spx (O-Spx) in terms of postoperative pain, length of hospital stay, and perioperative complications.6,7 However, some surgeons consider L-Spx for patients with portal hypertension to be contraindicated because of the high risk of massive intraoperative hemorrhage caused by splenomegaly, the existence of collateral vessels around the spleen, low platelet counts, and impaired coagulation factors.8,9

On the other hand, owing to the cumulative experiences of laparoscopic surgeries and recent advances in operating devices, especially vessel sealing systems, laparoscopic approaches have been increasingly indicated in various fields, including for patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension.10-12 In 2008, we also revised our standard operation for these patients from O-Spx and open Has (O-Has) to laparoscopic methods. The aim of this article is to more fully describe our method as well as the preliminary results of L-Spx and laparoscopic Has (L-Has).

sec.title: Patients and Methods
sec.p: Between August 1999 and August 2010, we operated on 110 cases of portal hypertension with Spx or Has. Among them, 56 patients who simultaneously underwent additional major operations such as hepatectomy were eliminated, leaving 54 patients enrolled in this study. They included 38 with open surgeries and 16 with laparoscopic surgeries consisting of 10 L-Spx and 6 L-Has operations. These 38 open surgeries included 33 O-Has and 5 O-Spxs; 13 Spxs were performed for severe pancytopenia, especially thrombocytopenia (platelet counts <3.0 × 104/µL), and the other 2 cases were for induction of interferon for hepatitis C infection. Since 2009, all cases of Spx and Has received pneumococcal vaccinations more than 1 month before the operation. The perioperative data, including patient characteristics, diagnosis, operative details, complications, and postoperative hospital stay for the 2 groups, were compared.

sec.title: Operative Procedures
sec.p: To reduce blood loss, patients whose platelet counts were less than 5.0 × 104/µL received platelet transfusion intraoperatively. Patients are placed in a semilateral position with the left flank elevated at a 45° angle. While dissecting the splenogastric ligaments and the splenic hilar pedicle, the operation bed is rotated to render the patient’s position horizontal. A 12-mm laparoscope trocar is inserted through an incision on the left side of the umbilicus, which is made by a minimal open laparotomy. A flexible-type laparoscope (LTF Type V3, Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) is introduced through the trocar. In cases of L-Spx, 2 other 12-mm trocars are inserted under visual control into the epigastric area and the left flank of the anterior axillar line (Figure 1). Splenic attachments are divided using electrocautery, an ultrasound dissector, and the LigaSure vessel-sealing system (Valleylab, Boulder, CO).

The splenogastric ligaments are first dissected using the LigaSure vessel-sealing system. Next, we dissect the splenocolic ligament and mobilized spleen to visualize the retroperitoneal attachments. Collateral vessels are often observed running around the lower pole of the spleen. The retroperitoneal splenic attachments that are covered by small collateral vessels are dissected using the LigaSure vessel-sealing system or an ultrasound dissector. After the upper pole of the spleen is entirely dissected away from the diaphragm, we transect the splenic hilar pedicles with an endoscopic linear vascular stapler (Endo-GIA, United States Surgical, Norwalk, CT). For cases in which the upper pole of the spleen is not sufficiently elevated because of an insufficient upper division of the spleen, we convert from a purely laparoscopic method to hand-assisted laparoscopic surgery (HALS). The resected spleen is put in a plastic bag and crushed with scissors through the hole used for the trocar before extraction.

In cases of L-Has, a 7- to 7.5-cm midline incision is made, and a hand port (LAP DISC, Ethicon Endo-Surgery, Cincinnati, OH) is introduced through the incision. A 12-mm trocar used mainly for devascularization of the upper stomach and abdominal esophagus is inserted in the left subcostal area in addition to 3 trocars for L-Spx (Figure 2). A Spx is performed using the same purely laparoscopic method (L-Spx) until the completion of splenic mobilization, unless bleeding occurs. Then, HALS is introduced from dissection of the splenic hilar pedicles. After the extraction of the spleen through the hand port, we start devascularization of the upper stomach and abdominal esophagus as shown by Yamamoto et al.13 Devascularization is performed in an inferior-to-superior direction, starting at the middle of the greater curvature of the stomach with the LigaSure vessel-sealing system. The gastrohepatic ligament is then opened and devascularization of the lesser curvature is performed by the same method. In patients with gastric varices, a large draining vein is seen in the area of the upper gastric fundus. This vessel is ligated with a 3-0 absorbable thread. After isolation of the anterior and posterior vagus nerves with the surgeon’s finger, nerves and vessels are dissected superior to a point about 7 cm from the esophagocardiac junction. To prevent a subsequent postvagotomy gastric outlet obstruction by a pylorospasm, pyloroplasty is performed by grasping the sphincter muscle, which can then be crushed to facilitate gastric emptying postoperatively (finger bougie method).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data are reported as mean ± standard deviation. Statistical analysis was performed using the unpaired Student’s t test for comparison between L-Has and L-Spx as well as between laparoscopic methods and open methods. Differences were considered significant if P < .05.
The ethical committee of the study hospital approved the study protocol.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The laparoscopic group included 15 patients with viral liver cirrhoses and 1 with idiopathic portal hypertension. The open group included 30 patients with viral liver cirrhoses, 4 with extrahepatic portal obstructions, 3 with idiopathic portal hypertension, and 1 with autoimmune hepatitis. There was no difference in Child-Pugh scores between the laparoscopic and open groups (6.0 ± 1.2 vs 6.0 ± 0.9).

The patient backgrounds and perioperative data for each patient who underwent laparoscopic surgeries are shown in Table 1. Purely L-Spx was completed for 9 patients. A conversion from laparoscopic to HALS was necessary for 1 patient (case 10) because of poor visualization around the upper pole of the spleen; total blood loss in this case was 632 mL. L-Has was performed for 6 patients with esophagogastric varices; there was no conversion from HALS to the open method. We experienced no uncontrollable hemorrhages, and sufficient devascularization of the upper stomach and abdominal esophagus was completed in all cases.

fn.p: Abbreviations: L-Spx, laparascopic splenectomy; L-Has, laparoscopic Hassab’s procedures; BMI, body mass index; C-LC, liver cirrhosis (type C); IPH, idiopathic portal hypertension; EV, esophageal varices; GV, gastric varices; PVT, portal vein thrombosis.

sec.p: The perioperative data for each patient who underwent L-Spx and L-Has are compared in Table 2. The operative time ranged from 113 to 325 minutes (224 ± 56 minutes), with intraoperative blood loss ranging from 0 to 1653 g (342 ± 513 g). No patient received a red blood cell transfusion. The postoperative stay ranged from 7 to 22 days (14.6 ± 3.5 days). Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) occurred in 1 case. No other complications were associated with the operation in the L-Spx group.

fn.p: Abbreviations: L-Spx, laparascopic splenectomy; L-Has, laparoscopic Hassab’s procedures; PVT, portal vein thrombosis.

sec.p: In L-Has patients, the causes of portal hypertension were 6 viral liver cirrhoses. The operative time ranged from 194 to 458 minutes (341 ± 94 minutes), with intraoperative blood loss ranging from 24 to 1065 g (531 ± 390 g). No patient required a red blood transfusion. Postoperative stay ranged from 8 to 41 days (19.8 ± 8.7 days). PVT occurred in 3 cases. One patient suffered from massive ascites. Operative time in L-Has was significantly longer than that in L-Spx. Postoperative hospital stays were shorter for L-Spx (14.6 ± 3.5 days) than for L-Has (19.8 ± 8.7 days), but the difference was not statistically significant. All patients who developed PVT in both groups were treated successfully by anticoagulation therapy.

Table 3 shows the comparison between L-Spx and O-Spx. The operative time was significantly longer for L-Spx (224 ± 56 minutes) than for the open method (135 ± 29 minutes). Blood loss was also increased in L-Spx (342 ± 513 g) compared with O-Spx (109 ± 77 g), though the difference was not statistically significant. The postoperative hospital stay was shorter in L-Spx (14.6 ± 3.5 days) than in O-Spx (19.4 ± 5.5 days), but the difference was not statistically significant.

fn.p: Abbreviations: L-Spx, laparascopic splenectomy; O-Spx, open splenectomy; PVT, portal vein thrombosis.

sec.p: Table 4 shows a comparison between L-Has and O-Has. Operative time was significantly longer in L-Has (341 ± 94 minutes) than in the open method (222 ± 52 minutes). However, there was no difference in blood loss between L-Has (531 ± 390 g) and O-Has (778 ± 555 g). As for complications, massive ascites were observed in 1 case in the L-Has group. On the other hand, in the O-Has group, surgical site infection occurred in 4 patients in addition to 3 massive ascite cases and 1 case of postoperative bleeding. There was a significant difference in complication rates between the 2 groups. The postoperative hospital stay was significantly shorter in the L-Has group (19.8 ± 8.7 days) than in the O-Has group (35.6 ± 16.9 days).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In spite of recent advances in laparoscopic technology, the majority of surgeons may still hesitate to perform laparoscopic surgeries for patients with portal hypertension because of the high risk of intraoperative massive hemorrhage as a result of low platelet counts and/or impaired coagulation factors. Moreover, splenomegaly and collateral vessels around the spleen make operative procedures difficult. A goal of the operation should entail the safe use of a minimally invasive technique. Portal hypertension from liver cirrhosis is still considered a contraindication to L-Spx in the clinical practice guidelines of the European Association for Endoscopic Surgery.14

The use of new methods should be based on reliable knowledge. Success with normal-sized and mildly enlarged spleens15,16 has led to an increasing use of L-Spx for patients with portal hypertension. In 1998, Hashizume et al17 had already reported the feasibility of laparoscopic surgery for patients with sclerotherapy-resistant esophagogastric varices. Recently, there have been increasing reports that describe the techniques for and safety of L-Spx for patients with portal hypertension.18-21

We have had extensive experience in the management of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension and are well versed in performing laparoscopic hepatectomies for hepatocellular carcinoma with liver cirrhosis.22-24 Among recent advances in laparoscopic surgeries, the introduction of vessel-sealing systems plays an important role. Recently, we tested them by dividing splenogastric ligaments or collateral vessels around the spleen in O-Spx and by devascularization of the upper stomach and abdominal esophagus in O-Has instead of using a noninstrumental, conventional method, that is, a transection after tying. We confirmed that they are sufficiently reliable for hemostasis in conditions such as portal hypertension. We consider that we are ready to undertake L-Spx and L-Has for patients with portal hypertension from cirrhosis and other causes. Based on the results of some of the reports mentioned above, we have chosen a pure laparoscopic method rather than HALS as a standard for Spx. Until now, we undertook L-Spx in 10 cases with no major complications without considering the patient’s spleen size or liver function. However, it was a preliminary experience in the 10 cases. Some reports have indicated that the pure laparoscopic method should be used with due consideration of spleen size for safety’s sake.9,25 We intend to increase the number of patients and take into account these important considerations. On the other hand, we consider that HALS is suitable at present for devascularization of the upper stomach because there are only a few reports about this technique, and devascularization of the upper stomach requires a more precise sense of touch. The use of HALS can overcome any technical hurdles and can make L-Has a safe procedure in settings of complete devascularization.26,27

In the present study, we compared the outcomes of patients who underwent open and laparoscopic surgeries in our hospital. Though the operative time was significantly longer in the L-Spx group, there were no other disadvantages. Postoperative hospital stay was shorter in the L-Spx group, but the difference between the 2 groups did not reach a significant level. One case was converted to HALS because of poor visualization of the upper pole of the spleen. The total blood loss in that case was 632 mL, and no blood transfusion was necessary. Quick decision making related to the change in strategy from a purely laparoscopic method to HALS is thought to be crucial.

The benefits of HALS in extremely difficult cases of splenomegaly and in patients who undergo devascularization of the upper stomach have been emphasized.13,25 To routinely perform L-Has safely on patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension, we decided on HALS as our treatment of choice. In our L-Has method, a purely laparoscopic method rather than HALS was chosen until the completion of splenic mobilization because the operator’s left hand tends to block full visualization around the spleen and to narrow the working space, especially in splenomegaly cases. From a dissection of splenic hilar pedicles, HALS was introduced as a steadier maneuver compared with the purely laparoscopic method. Isolation of the anterior and posterior vagus nerves and dissection of the nerves and vessels at a level superior to a point about 7 cm away from the esophagocardiac junction were safely completed in all cases with HALS. A finger bougie method of pyloroplasty was also performed in all cases through a midline incision.

Endoscopic treatment by endoscopic sclerotherapy or endoscopic variceal ligation is now the main treatment for esophagogastric varices. However, in Japan, especially, surgical treatment is often used for recurrent cases or solitary gastric varices.28,29 This was true of all the cases in the present study. Has is a representative method. Complete elimination of gastric varices can be expected this way, but esophageal varices usually cannot be entirely eradicated without adding endoscopic treatment.28 Following Has, complete disappearance of the varices was achieved by adding endoscopic treatment in all cases.

Among our L-Has cases, though the operative time was longer than that in O-Has cases, there was no such increase in the L-Has group. The rate of postoperative complications was significantly improved in the L-Has group, resulting in shorter postoperative hospital stays; also, there were no life-threatening complications in either group. However, surgical-site infections occurred in 4 cases of the O-Has group, which tended to prolong their postoperative stay and diminish their quality of life. Patients who underwent Has could eat within 2 to 3 days postoperatively. This operative procedure tends to cause postoperative gastric stasis as a result of severance of vagal nerves. In this connection, symptoms caused by gastric stasis were observed in 1 L-Has group case and 4 O-Has group cases. However, patient hospitalization duration did not increase as a result of this, and any differences between groups in this respect were a result of other complications.

Although Spx is growing in importance for patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension, the indications for Spx remain controversial because of PVT and septic complications. Recently, it has been reported that PVT is not a rare complication of Spx.30,31 In the present study, PVT occurred in 3 cases of L-Has and 1 case of L-Spx. Fortunately, they were treated successfully by anticoagulation therapy. However, all patients have been administered warfarin until today. On the other hand, post-Spx septic complications may be lethal. Pneumococcal vaccination before operation is crucial, elderly patients or those with low immune function should not be operated on, and indications should be strictly followed.

In conclusion, though L-Spx for patients with portal hypertension is a safe method, a timely strategy change to HALS for difficult cases is crucial. HALS, however, remains a safe and feasible strategy for Has at present. The long-term outcome of L-Has is important, but cases are few and observation times have been short. Thus, further study is warranted.
